text.title: Origins of US Racial Classifications
text.headline: When does the codification of race as a category of identity begin?
text.text: The U.S. government began keeping official records of racial classifications in the late 18th century. The first U.S. Census happened in 1790, not so coincidentally the same year that Congress passed the Naturalization Act, which restricted the right of adopted citizenship to "FREE WHITE" people only. These historical facts set the context leading to Susie Phipps' legal challenge to change her racial classification.

text.headline: Hypo-descent law
text.text: Louisiana Hypo-descent law passes, which is based on colonial era "ONE DROP RULE" in which anyone with 1/32 or more African ancestry is considered "BLACK."

text.headline: Passport Denied
text.text: Phipps checks "WHITE" on her passport application, and she was then denied a passport because her birth certificate indicated "COLORED" for one of her parents.

text.headline: Racial Classification
text.text: Susie Phipps decided to sue to challenge her racial classification as something other than "WHITE." A Tulane professor studying the case states that most whites have 1/20 African-American blood.

text.headline: The Great Discovery
text.text: Phipps's great-great-great-great grandmother [Margarita] was revealed to have been a slave. In a 1983 interview, Phipps was quoted that she came to believe that "Margarita had been DARK rather than BLACK."

text.headline: Standing for your beliefs
text.text: Phipps claimed she held no grudge against BLACK people and rather she only stood up for what she believed: she was WHITE. If her birth certificate didn't get corrected, descendants might misunderstand their own racial lineage.

text.headline: Phipps goes to trial
text.text: Phipps testifies that "this classification came as a shock, since she had always thought she was WHITE, had lived as WHITE, had twice married as WHITE."

text.headline: US Supreme court case refusal
text.text: U.S. Supreme Court upholds the decision to refuse to hear a case exposing Louisiana's racial classification criteria.
